Fig. 1 XRD patterns of freshly reduced catalysts and used catalysts. (a) Co–Zn–Al–O catalysts; (b) Co–Al–O catalysts. Line “A0” represents sample “A0” whilst other lines follow this rule. “ZnO (36–1451)”, “Co° (15–806)”, “ZnAl2O4 (5–669)” and “γ-Al2O3 (10–425)” represent JCPDS cards #36–1451 (ZnO), #15–806 (Co°), #5–669 (ZnAl2O4) and #10–425 (γ-Al2O3) respectively and all follow the left Y axis. The XRD patterns of catalysts follow the right Y axis. Fig. 2 FESEM images of freshly reduced samples and used samples. Fig. 3 CO conversions of catalysts during sulfur addition tests. (1) 100ppm S addition test over Co/γ-Al2O3. (2–4): 0.1–1, 10, 100ppm S addition tests over Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 respectively. S was introduced right after the “a” points. For line (2), 0.1ppm S was introduced right after the “a” point while the S introduction was switched to 1ppm S right after the “b” point. For line (4), introduction of S was paused right after the “c” points and was resumed right after the “a” points. Fig. 4 CO2 selectivities of catalysts during sulfur addition tests. (1) 100ppm S addition test over Co/γ-Al2O3. (2–4): 0.1–1, 10, 100ppm S addition tests over Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 respectively. S was introduced right after the “a” points. For line (2), 0.1ppm S was introduced right after the “a” point while the S introduction was switched to 1ppm S right after the “b” point. Effect of in-situ sulfur poisoning on zinc-containing spinel-supported cobalt CO hydrogenation catalyst Zhenxin Liu ⁎ Depeng Wu Yu Xing ⁎ Xuehui Guo Shaoming Fang ⁎ Henan Provincial Key Laboratory of Surface and Interface Science, School of Materials and Chemical Engineering, Zhengzhou University of Light Industry, Zhengzhou 450002, China Henan Provincial Key Laboratory of Surface and Interface Science School of Materials and Chemical Engineering Zhengzhou University of Light Industry Zhengzhou 450002 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: +86 371 86609676. Graphical abstract The concentration of S in feedstock has significant effect on catalytic activity. The rate of S sorption by Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst at 100ppmv S is 3.1 times higher than that by Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, making the former a potential catalyst (or sorbent) to be loaded at the top portion (or pre-catalytic bed) of a fixed-bed FT reactor to scavenge sulfur from syngas feedstock. Literature about sulfur addition over AB2O4 spinel-supported cobalt CO hydrogenation catalysts is sparse. Research about the use of carbon disulfide as the sulfur carrier for the poisoning of cobalt catalysts is also sparse. In this study, effect of the addition of 0.1–1, 10, 100 and 300ppmv of sulfur (injected as carbon disulfide) on the structure and performance of a Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 CO hydrogenation catalyst was characterized (by ICP, XRD, nitrogen sorption and FESEM) and evaluated in a fixed-bed reactor. The addition of 0.1–1ppmv of sulfur did not have a significant negative effect on the activity of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst. At S equivalent concentration of 100ppmv, the deactivation of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst was reversible to some extent. At identical S equivalent concentration of 100ppmv, the rate of S sorption by Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst was 3.1 times higher than that by Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, making the former a potential catalyst (or sorbent) to be loaded at the top portion (or pre-catalytic bed) of a fixed-bed FT reactor to scavenge sulfur from syngas feedstock. Keywords CO hydrogenation Cobalt catalyst Sulfur poisoning Deactivation Fischer-Tropsch synthesis 1 Introduction Co°/support catalysts have various applications in hydrogenation of carbon monoxide (e.g., Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS)) [1–4] or hydrogenation of unsaturated organic molecules [5,6]. Many studies have focused on the deactivation by sulfur/chlorine over conventional iron-based [7–12] and cobalt-based [13–16] CO hydrogenation catalysts [17]. There are two major methods for the study of sulfur poisoning on cobalt catalysts: in-situ sulfur addition and ex-situ sulfur addition. In-situ sulfur addition is a continuous injection of sulfur-containing matter (e.g., H2S, (CH3)2S, C4H10S) into a reactor [14,18–23], while ex-situ sulfur addition is usually an impregnation of a catalyst with the solution of sulfur-containing salt (e.g., (NH4)2S, (NH4)2SO4, (NH4)2SO3, Na2S) before loaded in a reactor [9,15,16,24,25]. Sulfur may bind itself strongly with active sites, form undesired metal sulfides on the surface and suppress the adsorption of reactants on the active sites [18,26]. It is also reported that sulfur may cause some beneficial effect on the performance of cobalt catalysts [15]. As mentioned by Bambal et al., the role of sulfur varies with the type of catalyst and the operating conditions used [18]. Compared with simple oxides (e.g., silica or alumina), complex oxides (e.g., AB2O4 spinels) own higher resistance against sintering/steam and may suppress the formation of metal-support compounds [27,28]. Recently we reported the synthesis, characterization and CO hydrogenation performance of ZnAl2O4 spinel-supported cobalt catalyst [29] as well as the effect of deliberate water addition over the performance of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst [30]. Literature about sulfur addition over AB2O4 spinel-supported cobalt CO hydrogenation catalysts is sparse. Research about the use of carbon disulfide as the sulfur carrier for the poisoning of cobalt catalysts is also sparse. In this article we report the effect of sulfur addition on ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 supported cobalt CO hydrogenation catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of materials Our previous investigation shows that impregnation of the ZnAl2O4-type support with cobalt nitrate solution will cause considerable decomposition of crystalline ZnAl2O4 phase to crystalline ZnO phase and X-ray amorphous Al2O3 phase [29]. Therefore a method based on coprecipitation is employed in this article to prepare Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst. The preparation procedures of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 and Co/γ-Al2O3 are addressed in Supplementary data section, which follows our previous report [30]. The nomenclature of samples was listed in Table 1 . The freshly reduced samples (i.e., A0 and B0) for characterizations are reduced by an atmosphere of 50% H2/50% He in quartz boats loaded in a horizontal tubular furnace. After the in-situ reduction and FTS reactions as well as subsequent cooling down processes, the used catalysts were taken out of a vertical tubular furnace (i.e., the fixed-bed reactor) of the apparatus for ex-situ characterizations. All samples were taken out at RT without inert blanketing and then were reserved in glass vials in air atmosphere. 2.2 Structural characterization After the reduction or FTS reactions as well as subsequent cooling down processes, the catalysts were taken out of tubular furnaces at RT without inert blanketing and then reserved in glass vials in air atmosphere for ex-situ characterizations. Any sample of a used catalyst is a mixture of the catalytic material loaded in the reactor. Crystalline phases were identified by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a Panalytical X'Pert Pro diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The average crystallite size was determined by X-ray diffraction line broadening analysis (LBA), where the data of full width at half maximum (FWHM) were employed and the instrumental broadening was corrected using the XRD data of LaB6 reference material [31–34]. The symbol “L Co(111)” denotes the average size of fcc Co° crystallites in the direction perpendicular to the (111) reflecting planes. The symbol “L ZnAl2O4(311)” denotes the average size of ZnAl2O4 crystallites in the direction perpendicular to the (311) reflecting planes. Relevant results are shown in Table 1, Fig. 1 and Supplementary data Figs. S1–S7. A Leeman PROFILE SPEC ICP (Inductive Coupled Plasma Emission Spectrometer) was used for elemental analysis. A Quantachrome NOVA1000 surface area and pore size analyzer was used for nitrogen sorption measurements. Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) studies were carried out using a Hitachi S-4700 FESEM. A Nicolet Magna-IR 750 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer was used for FT-IR studies. 2.3 Catalytic performance tests The FT synthesis was carried out in a fixed-bed tubular reactor built by Tianjin Tian-Da-Bei-Yang ChE Experimental Equipment LLC. Firstly, unreduced catalyst (40–60mesh) was loaded and then reduced by 50% H2/50% He at 550°C under atmospheric pressure. During the period that is free of sulfur, the in-situ reduced sample is tested with a syngas (H2:CO:Ar=6:3:1, by mole%) at 2.0MPa and a space velocity (SV) of 700mLg cat−1 h−1. Sulfur addition tests were carried out using a procedure similar to Bambal et al. [18]. In this article, CS2 is employed as the sulfur carrier whilst n-octane is used as the solvent of CS2. During the period that sulfur is introduced, a solution of CS2 in n-octane supplied from a SSI-II pump (made by USA) at 0.01mL/min is vaporized and mixed with the synthesis gas just before reaching the reactor inlet. The concentration of CS2 in feed at the reactor inlet is 0.05, 0.5, 5, 50 or 150ppmv, which has a concentration of S (equivalent) in feed at the reactor inlet of 0.1, 1, 10, 100 or 300ppmv respectively. Argon, the internal standard gas, is not counted in the calculation about the concentration of CS2 in feed at the reactor inlet. Bambal et al. employed butanethiol (C4H10S) as the sulfur carrier and n-octane (C8H18) as the solvent to investigate the poisoning of Co/SiO2 catalysts at the concentrations of 10 and 50ppm S equivalent [18]. Their data of calibration run show that n-octane, as a solvent, displays no measurable effect toward the Co/SiO2 catalysts under FTS conditions [18]. To rule out the effect of n-octane, a calibration run with the addition of pure n-octane (i.e., free of CS2) was also performed. Supplementary data Fig. S8 shows that n-octane, the solvent of CS2, has no obvious effect toward the Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst under the FTS condition. The interferences of n-octane with the C8 peaks of FT product analysis have been resolved by performing the calibration run. The tests are conducted with the loading of unreduced catalyst. The flow rates and partial pressures of CO (p (CO) =0.6MPa) and H2 ( p ( H 2 ) = 1.2 Mpa ) remain unchanged during all of the tests. The reaction temperature is 240°C for all tests. Argon was employed as the internal standard component of syngas for GC analysis. CO, CH4 and CO2 were analyzed by a GC with a TCD detector equipped with a TDX-01 packed column (3m in length). Incondensable gaseous hydrocarbons were analyzed by a GC with a FID detector equipped with a PLOT Al2O3/S (50m×0.53mm×25μm) capillary column. Condensed oil and wax (dissolved in toluene) were analyzed by a GC with a FID detector equipped with an OV-101 (50m×0.25mm×0.5μm) capillary column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure & texture features of catalysts The XRD patterns of freshly reduced catalysts and used catalysts were shown in Fig. 1 and Supplementary data Figs. S1–7. Sample A0 is a freshly reduced catalyst consisting of cubic Co° phase (JCPDS: 15–806) and ZnAl2O4 spinel phase (JCPDS: 5–669) while its Al2O3 phase seems X-ray amorphous. As listed in Fig. 1, after the sulfur addition tests with 0.1–1, 10, 100 and 300ppmv S (equivalent) in feed, this Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst became used catalysts A1–4 respectively. Other than the Co° phase and ZnAl2O4 phase, crystalline wax (which has two characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ of 21.5° and 23.8° [35]) is another crystalline phase in used catalysts A1–3. The diffraction peaks of Co° phase in used catalyst A4 is weaker than those in samples A0–A3. The diffraction peaks of ZnO phase (JCPDS: 36–1451) are significant in used catalyst A4, suggesting that the ZnAl2O4 phase has been decomposed to generate the ZnO phase during the sulfur addition test of 300ppmv S equivalent. Sample A4 has impurity peaks at 2θ of 41.1°, 42.7° and 45.6°, of which the affiliations remain unclear so far. Sample B0 is a freshly reduced catalyst consisting of cubic Co° phase and γ-Al2O3 phase (JCPDS: 10–425). Other than the Co° phase and γ-Al2O3 phase, crystalline wax is another crystalline phase in used catalysts B3. As listed in Table 1, the sulfur addition tests with 0.1–1, 10 and 100ppmv S (equivalent) lower down the average Co° crystallite size (L Co(111)) of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst from 7.6nm to 5.8, 4.9 and 5.0 nm, respectively. However, the sulfur addition test with 300ppmv S (equivalent) increases the average Co° crystallite size (L Co(111)) of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst from 7.6nm to 11.8nm. Different from the case of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst, the sulfur addition test with 100ppmv S (equivalent) increases the average Co° crystallite size (L Co(111)) of Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst from 12.1nm to 15.3nm. As shown in Table 1, the sulfur addition tests with 0.1–1, 10 and 100ppmv S (equivalent) lower down the BET specific surface area of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst from 151.1m2/g to 22.9, 32.5 and 15.2m2/g, respectively. And the sulfur addition test with 100ppmv S (equivalent) decreases the BET specific surface area of Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst from 128.6m2/g to 19.6m2/g. A possible reason for these specific surface area losses is contributed to the collapse of pores or sintering of particles. However, this Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst has been verified by our recent investigation to own good sintering-resistance against the steam/hydrothermal environment of FTS [30]. Therefore, the major reason for these specific surface area losses is probably due to the filling in their pores with wax product. The sulfur addition test with 300ppmv S (equivalent) lowers down the BET specific surface area of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst from 151.1m2/g to 25.8m2/g. The diffraction peaks of crystalline wax are almost invisible in sample A4, indicating that the filling with wax might be a reason but may not be the major reason for this specific surface area loss, which may also possibly be due to the decomposition of ZnAl2O4 as confirmed by its XRD pattern. 3.2 Rate of sulfur sorption by catalysts The data about sulfur sorption by catalysts are shown in Table 1 and Supplementary data Table S1. The rate of S sorption by catalyst is determined by Eq. (1): (1) Rate of S sorption by catalyst = ( 1 g cat. ) × ( ICP concentration of S in used cat.) × ( 10 6 u g/g ) ( accumulative duration of i n − s i t u sulfur addition ) Used catalysts A1, A2 and A3 have increasing rate of S sorption by catalyst of 0.09, 0. 15 and 1.11μg S/(hg cat.) respectively, which are consistent with the increasing sulfur concentrations in feed during the sulfur addition tests. Both being treated with 100ppmv S equivalent in feed, the rate of S sorption by Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst (i.e., 1.11μg S/(hg cat.)) is 3.1 times higher than that by Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (i.e., 0.27μg S/(hg cat.)), suggesting that the Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst is able to sorb significantly more sulfur than the Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst at identical reaction time. During the sulfur addition test with 300ppmv S equivalent in feed, the rate of S sorption by Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst (i.e., 0.56μg S/(hg cat.)) is less than that with 100ppmv S equivalent in feed. The reason is possibly due to the devastating effect of 300ppmv S equivalent in feed, which decomposes the ZnAl2O4 support phase. As shown in Supplementary data Table S1, in the case of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst, the ratios of catalyst-sorbed S to supplied S equivalent are 13.74%, 1.54% and 1.14% as the concentrations of S equivalent in feed are 0.1–1, 10 and 100ppmv, respectively. These facts indicate that, at low concentration of S equivalent in feed (i.e., 0.1–1ppmv), Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst may sorb significantly higher proportion of S equivalent from feed than at higher concentrations of S equivalent in feed (i.e., 10 or 100ppmv). Therefore the Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst is possible to become a potential catalyst (or sorbent) to be loaded at the top portion (or pre-catalytic bed) of a fixed-bed FT reactor to scavenge sulfur from syngas feedstock. The ICP and XRD results suggest that the sulfur addition with 300ppmv S equivalent in feed may affect the bulk of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst (e.g., decomposing the ZnAl2O4 support phase), while the sulfur addition with 100ppmv or less S equivalent in feed does not affect the bulk and thus may be adsorbed mainly on the surface of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst. The total amount of sorbed S increases from 18 to 186μg with increasing S concentration (i.e., 0.1–1, 10 and 100ppmv) in the feed but drops from 186 to 78μg at the very high S concentration (i.e., 300ppmv) in the feed. It looks like there is a limited absolute quantity of sorbed S, which is probably due to the change of bulk structure of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst at the very high S concentration (i.e., 300ppmv) in the feed. By using a column sorption method [36], the saturated adsorption amount of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst is determined to be 234.6mg (CS2) per gram catalyst. 3.3 Electron microscopy studies FESEM is used to observe the morphology of cobalt catalysts. As shown in Fig. 2 (a) & (g), both freshly reduced catalysts (i.e., A0 and B0) are nanocomposites under electron microscopy studies. As shown in Fig. 2(b)–(d) and (h), after the sulfur addition tests of 100 or less ppmv S equivalent in feed, the aggregates of particles in catalysts become swollen as if covered or filled by bright and smooth matter which may be the wax products. After the sulfur addition test of 300ppmv S equivalent in feed, the morphology of Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst has been completely changed from aggregates of nanoparticles to aggregates of micro-scale leaflike flakes (Fig. 2(e) & (f)), of which this flake morphology might be formed mainly through the growth of ZnO phase in the hydrothermal environment of FTS due to the poor sintering resistance of ZnO phase [32]. 3.4 Catalytic performance Catalytic activity. Line (1) of Fig. 3 shows that the CO conversion of Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst remains 100% during the period (50h) of sulfur-free feeding. Line (1) of Fig. 3 also shows that, during the sulfur addition with 100ppmv S equivalent in feed, the CO conversion of Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst remains 100% during the initial 12h of sulfur addition and then exhibits a trend of gradual drop from 100% to 88% during the last 116h of sulfur addition. These facts indicates that introduction of CS2 is effective to poison conventional Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Line (1) of Fig. 3 also shows that the drop of CO conversion during sulfur addition seems wavelike rather than smoothly. Although the SSI-II pump is announced to be “virtually pulse-free”, one may still wonder if this wavelike drop of CO conversion is related with the pulse pumping of CS2 in n-octane at a very low liquid flow rate of 0.01mL/min. In the case of sulfur-free feeding, the CO conversion of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst is ca. 68% at 240°C (Supplementary data Fig. S8). Line (2) of Figs. 3 & 4(b) shows that, during the sulfur addition with 0.1ppmv S equivalent in feed (i.e., from point “a” to point “b”), the CO conversion of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst increases slightly, indicating that ultra low concentration of S (i.e., 0.1ppmv S equivalent in feed) may facilitate the conversion of CO. Line (2) of Figs. 3 & 4(b) also shows that, during the sulfur addition with 1ppmv S equivalent in feed (i.e., after point “b”), the CO conversion of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst undulates around 79% and does not deviate significantly, indicating that low concentration of S (i.e., 1ppmv S equivalent in feed) neither facilitates nor suppress the conversion of CO during this test. Line (3) of Figs. 3 & 4(c) shows that, during the sulfur addition with 10ppmv S equivalent in feed, the CO conversion of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst decreases slightly, indicating that this medium concentration of S (i.e., 10ppmv S equivalent in feed) may slightly suppress the conversion of CO. Line (4) of Figs. 3 & 4(d) shows that, during the sulfur addition with 100ppmv S equivalent in feed, the CO conversion of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst drops significanly. Once the sulfur addition of 100ppmv S equivalent is paused, the CO conversion of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst may recover to some extent. These facts indicate that this high concentration of S (i.e., 100ppmv S equivalent in feed) may significantly suppress the conversion of CO. At S equivalent concentration of 100ppmv, the deactivation of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst is reversible to some extent, indicating that the adsorption of sulfur species by Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst might be reversible to some extent during the 100ppm S addition. As shown in Supplementary data Fig. S9, after an equal in-situ sulfidation time of ca. 46.5h, the CO conversions of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst under the sulfur addition tests with 0.1–1, 10, 100 and 300ppmv S equivalent in feed are 77%, 62%, 54% and 3%, respectively. These facts shows that the concentration of S has significant effect on the activity of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst. The ultra high concentration of S (i.e., 300ppmv S equivalent in feed) has devastating effect on the activity of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst, probably by destroying the structure of catalyst as verified by the XRD results. CO2 selectivity Ojeda et al. considered CO2 as a product of direct CO dissociation, which will happen more significantly at higher temperatures or higher conversions [37]. Line (1) of Fig. 4 (a) shows that, during the sulfur addition with 100ppmv S equivalent in feed, the CO2 selectivity of Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst drops significantly from 13% to 4% as the CO conversion decreases from 100% to 88%. Lines (2–4) of Fig. 4(b–d) show that, generally to say, the CO2 selectivities have similar trends as their relevant CO conversions. These facts indicate that the addition of sulfur may change the CO2 selectivity by changing the activity of Co/γ-Al2O3 or Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalysts. Hydrocarbon product distribution (C5+) The effect of sulfur addition on hydrocarbon product distribution of Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst has been studied by Visconti et al. [23]. This article reports the effect of sulfur addition on hydrocarbon product distribution of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst. Figs. 5–7 show the hydrocarbon product distributions based on C by mole, representing the selectivities of C5+, C2–C4 and C1 (i.e., CH4) respectively without counting in CO2. For example, the C1 (i.e., CH4) hydrocarbon distribution equals to the ratio of the number of C in CH4 molecules to the number of C in all hydrocarbon molecules. The C5+ hydrocarbon distribution equals to the ratio of the number of C in C5+ molecules to the number of C in all hydrocarbon molecules. It is known that, for a certain FTS catalyst, the decrease of CO conversion is preferential for the formation of C5+ (heavy products) [38]. This is consistent with our data (which will be published elsewhere) on Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst. Therefore, as the CO conversion deceases as shown on the upper line (4) of Fig. 5(d) (i.e., from points “a” to subsequent points “c” as well as after the third point “a”), the relevant C5+ hydrocarbon distribution value is supposed to increase if this sulfur addition has no effect. However, during this sulfur addition with 100ppmv S equivalent in feed, the C5+ hydrocarbon distribution value actually decreases to some extent as shown on the lower line (4) of Fig. 5(d) (i.e., from points “a” to subsequent points “c” as well as after the third point “a”). This fact suggests that the sulfur addition with 100ppmv S equivalent in feed may effectively suppress the formation of C5+ (heavy products). However, during the sulfur addition with 0.1–1as well as 10ppmv S equivalent in feed (as shown in Fig. 5(b) & (c)), the effect of sulfur addition on C5+ hydrocarbon distribution becomes insignificant and are difficult to tell because both their changes of CO conversion and their concentrations of sulfur are much less significant than those for the case of 100ppmv S equivalent in feed. Hydrocarbon product distribution (C2–C4). It is known that, for a certain FTS catalyst, the decrease of CO conversion is not preferential for the formation of light products (e.g., C2–C4 and CH4) [38]. Therefore, as the CO conversion deceases as shown on the upper line (4) of Fig. 6(d) (i.e., from points “a” to subsequent points “c” as well as after the third point “a”), the relevant C2–C4 hydrocarbon distribution value is supposed to decrease if this sulfur addition has no effect. However, during this sulfur addition with 100ppmv S equivalent in feed, the C2–C4 hydrocarbon distribution value actually increases to some extent as shown on the lower line (4) of Fig. 6(d) (i.e., from points “a” to subsequent points “c” as well as after the third point “a”). This fact suggests that the sulfur addition with 100ppmv S equivalent in feed may effectively enhance the formation of C2–C4 (a fraction of light products). However, during the sulfur addition with 0.1–1as well as 10ppmv S equivalent in feed (as shown in Fig. 6(b) & (c)), the effect of sulfur addition on C2–C4 hydrocarbon distribution becomes insignificant and are difficult to tell because both their changes of CO conversion and their concentrations of sulfur are much less significant than those for the case of 100ppmv S equivalent in feed. Hydrocarbon product distribution (CH4). It is known that, for a certain FTS catalyst, the decrease of CO conversion is not preferential for the formation of light products (e.g., CH4 and C2–C4) [38]. Therefore, as the CO conversion deceases as shown on the upper line (4) of Fig. 7(d) (i.e., from points “a” to subsequent points “c” as well as after the third point “a”), the relevant CH4 hydrocarbon distribution value is supposed to decrease if this sulfur addition has no effect. However, during this sulfur addition with 100ppmv S equivalent in feed, the CH4 hydrocarbon distribution value does not simply decrease but becomes vibratory. This fact indicates that the sulfur addition with 100ppmv S equivalent in feed may enhance the formation of CH4 (a fraction of light products) to counteract the declining trend caused by the decrease of CO conversion. However, during the sulfur addition with 0.1–1as well as 10ppmv S equivalent in feed (as shown in Fig. 7(b) & (c)), the effect of sulfur addition on CH4 hydrocarbon distribution becomes insignificant and are difficult to tell because both their changes of CO conversion and their concentrations of sulfur are much less significant than those for the case of 100ppmv S equivalent in feed. C2–C4 olefin/paraffin ratio. It is known that, for a certain FTS catalyst, the decrease of CO conversion is preferential for the formation of more olefins in products [38]. The lower line (4) of Fig. 8 shows that, during the sulfur addition with 100ppmv S equivalent in feed, the C2–C4 olefin/paraffin ratio of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst does increase as the CO conversion deceases (which is shown on the upper line (4) of Fig. 8, i.e., from points “a” to subsequent points “c” as well as after the third point “a”). This fact indicates that the sulfur addition with 100ppmv S equivalent in feed may enhance the C2–C4 olefin/paraffin ratio by suppressing the activity of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalysts. As an example, the α value (i.e., chain growth probability [39] calculated from the ASF product distribution) of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst before and after the first time 100ppm S addition is 0.79 and 0.77, respectively. 3.5 Infrared studies Due to the shortage of in-situ characterization equipment in our laboratory for the 2.0MPa CO hydrogenation, the ex-situ FT-IR spectra of some Co–Al–O and Co–Zn–Al–O catalysts were collected instead and shown in Supplementary data Figs. S10 and S11. The absorption bands of all eleven curves at −3420cm−1 and −1616cm−1 can be ascribed to OH stretching of physisorbed water and H2O bending, respectively [40]. The absorption peaks of curves 3, 4 and 7–10 at −2945cm−1, ×2916cm−​1, −2847cm−​1, −1462cm−​1 and −713cm−1 can be respectively assigned to asymmetry CH2 stretching, methylene nonsymmetry stretch vibration, methylene symmetry stretch vibration, methylene nonsymmetry changing angle vibration and methylene swing in plane vibration, which are originated from the hydrocarbons retained in catalysts [40–42]. The band of curves 3, 4 and 7–10 at −1543cm−​1 cannot be simply ascribed to the C​C stretching vibration, because it could also possibly be due to carbonate species, likely to be formed on the oxide surface since the samples were exposed to air before the IR analysis [43]. The bands of curve 1 at −660cm−​1 and −540cm−​1 are attributed to the intrinsic structure of γ-Al2O3 support, while the bands of curve 5 at −680cm−​1 and −540cm−​1 are attributed to the intrinsic structure of ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 support [40]. The freshly reduced catalysts A0 and B0, as shown in curves 6 and 2, also have the 2945, 2916 and 2847cm−​1 bands but these bands are much weaker than those in the catalysts after the FTS reactions, of which the reason remains unclear. Curve 11 does not have strong 2916 and 2847cm−​1 bands, of which the reason may be the rapid structure damage and deactivation caused by the 300ppm S addition. Zhou and Andrews pointed out that the infrared absorption of the Co-CS2 neutral complexes are at 1338, 1250, 1173, 613 and 516cm−​1, while the infrared absorption of the Co–CS2 cation complexes are at 1405, 1373, 1363, 975 and 485cm−​1 [44]. Our infrared studies did not find any bands of Co–CS2 neutral/cation complexes. CS2 is often used as the precursor for H2S [45,46]. For CS2, the reaction with hydrogen to H2S is relatively fast and proceeds via the methylmercaptan intermediate [45]. Su et al. reported the poisoning of Ni​/Al2O3 catalyst by CS2 and proposed a mechanism that first CS2 reacts with H2 to form H2S plus CH4, and then H2S reacts with nickel atoms to form nickel sulfide species, causing poisoning of the active metal [46]. We agree with this mechanism which might be similar to our cobalt catalysts. 4 Conclusions In-situ injection of CS2 at S equivalent concentration of 100ppmv is effective to poison both Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst and conventional Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. S equivalent concentration of 0.1ppmv has slightly positive effect on the activity of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst. S equivalent concentration of 1ppmv has no significant negative effect on the activity of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst. S equivalent concentration of 10ppmv has slightly negative effect on the activity of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst. S equivalent concentration of 100ppmv has significant negative effect on the activity of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst. S equivalent concentration of 300ppmv has devastating effect on the activity of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst. S equivalent concentrations of 0.1–100ppmv have no significant effect on the structure of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst, while S equivalent concentration of 300ppmv may decompose the ZnAl2O4 phase. At S equivalent concentration of 100ppmv, the addition of sulfur may lower down the CO conversion, the CO2 selectivity and the formation of heavy products (i.e., C5+), and may enhance the C2–C4 olefin/paraffin ratio and the formation of light hydrocarbons (i.e., C1–C4). At identical S equivalent concentration of 100ppmv, the rate of S sorption by Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst is 3.1 times higher than that by Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. At low S concentrations (i.e., 0.1–1ppmv), Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst may sorb significantly higher proportion of S equivalent from feed than at higher S concentrations (i.e., 10 or 100ppmv). At S equivalent concentration of 100ppmv, the deactivation of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst is reversible to some extent. Our future work is to explore the Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst as a potential catalyst (or sorbent) to be loaded at the top portion (or pre-catalytic bed) of a fixed-bed FT reactor. coredata.dc:description: Literature about sulfur addition over AB2O4 spinel-supported cobalt CO hydrogenation catalysts is sparse. Research about the use of carbon disulfide as the sulfur carrier for the poisoning of cobalt catalysts is also sparse. In this study, effect of the addition of 0.1–1, 10, 100 and 300ppmv of sulfur (injected as carbon disulfide) on the structure and performance of a Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 CO hydrogenation catalyst was characterized (by ICP, XRD, nitrogen sorption and FESEM) and evaluated in a fixed-bed reactor. The addition of 0.1–1ppmv of sulfur did not have a significant negative effect on the activity of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst. At S equivalent concentration of 100ppmv, the deactivation of Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst was reversible to some extent. At identical S equivalent concentration of 100ppmv, the rate of S sorption by Co/ZnAl2O4·Al2O3 catalyst was 3.1 times higher than that by Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, making the former a potential catalyst (or sorbent) to be loaded at the top portion (or pre-catalytic bed) of a fixed-bed FT reactor to scavenge sulfur from syngas feedstock.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of in-situ sulfur poisoning on zinc-containing spinel-supported cobalt CO hydrogenation catalyst
